bio:
As inscribed by Nobuhide Ohama at his memorial: “Funakoshi Gichin (?? ??) Sensei, of karate-do, was born on June 10, 1870, in Shuri, Okinawa. From about eleven years old he began to study to-te jutsu under Azato Anko and Itosu Anko. He practiced diligently and in 1912 became the president of the Okinawan Shobukai. In May 1922, he relocated to Tokyo and became a professional teacher of karate-do. He devoted his entire life to the development of karate-do. He lived out his eighty-eight years of life and left this world on April 26, 1957. Reinterpreting to-te jutsu, the Sensei promulgated karate-do while not losing its original philosophy. Like bugei (classical martial arts), so too is the pinnacle of karate mu (enlightenment): to purify and make one empty through the transformation from jutsu to do. Through his famous words '???????' (karate ni sente nashi), meaning 'There is no first attack in Karate,' and ???????? (karate wa kunshi no bugei), meaning 'Karate is the martial art of intelligent people,' Sensei helped us to better understand the term jutsu. In an effort to commemorate his virtue and great contributions to modern karate-do as a pioneer, we, his loyal students, organised the Shotokai and erected this monument at the Enkakuji. Kenzen ichi' ('The fist and Zen are one').{r=54}

Life

Gichin Funakoshi was born in Shuri, Okinawa on November 10, 1868, the year of the Meiji Restoration. His father's name was Gisu.{r=54} As a member of the Tominakoshi family, he was shizoku, a low level of nobility. However, he was forced to work beneath his station, reportedly in the rice paddies, because his alcoholic father wasted the family’s money.{r=55}

After entering primary school, he became close friends with the son of Ank? Azato, a t?di (the Okinawan name for karate, also known as t?-te) and Jigen-ry? (sword) master who would soon become his first karate teacher.{r=54}

Funakoshi began training under Azato, an Okinawan government official, at eleven years old.{r=55} At first, he was Azato's only student.{r=52} Though frequently ill and weak, his training was supplemented by toudi master Anko Itotsu{r=55} and others such as Piechin Kiyuna and Niigaki and Sokon Matsumura,{r=52} following the Okinawan tradition of traveling and learning from many sources. The t?di Funakoshi studied was not as militaristic in training as karate would be by the mid-20th century, and it was practiced as a sport: bare-knuckled competitions occurred from time to time, in which Itotsu reportedly participated.{r=55}

As Funakoshi's family was stiffly opposed to the abolition of the Japanese topknot, this meant he would be ineligible to attend medical school, despite having passed the entrance examination. Being trained in both classical Chinese and Japanese philosophies and teachings, he became an assistant teacher. During this time, his relations with the Azato family grew and he began nightly travels to the Azato family residence to receive karate instruction from Ank? Azato.{r=54}

While teaching “Chinese Classics" to children in a public school, Funakoshi, following Itotsu’s creation of Pinan kata for middle schools, created and began to teach the Taikyoku kata in elementary schools.{r=55}

By the time Funakoshi’s karate was ready for Japanese reception, it was reputedly a synthesis of Okinawan martial arts, coming mainly from both popular styles of t?di at the time: Sh?rei-ry? (Naha-te) and Sh?rin-ry? (Shuri-te){r=54} Rob Redmond, however, argues that Funakoshi’s karate was mostly from Shuri-te, and that the Naha-te elements came from kata introduced by his students.{r=55} Funakoshi's interpretation of a character in karate to mean "empty" was reported to have caused some recoil in Okinawa, prompting him in 1922 to remain in Tokyo indefinitely.{r=54} Yet Redmond points out that as early as 1905, Okinawans were writing the word interchangeably between “T’ang" (China) and “empty." But because he was a prolific and popular writer, and because Japan was receptive to that change in its increasing imperialism, he has been credited with that interpretation.{r=55}

Funakoshi got osteoarthritis in 1948 and died of colorectal cancer in 1957.{r=54} In reflection of his long life and karate career, Redmond writes, “[Funakoshi] was a clever businessman and marketer. He was a social chameleon who was able to discern the times and take advantage appropriately. ...He was brought to Japan, care for there, and then recruited by the US government all because of his uniquely captivating personality and his well-reputed skill at politics. ...When I look at his picture, I see a sweet old man who came from a simple place who enjoyed his athletic activity so much that he wanted everyone to do it with him. ...Funakoshi was a human being in the right place, at the right time, in the right circumstances, and stepped onto that boat."{r=55}

A memorial to Gichin Funakoshi was erected by the Shotokai at Engaku-ji, a temple in Kamakura, on December 1, 1968. Designed by Kenji Ogata, the monument features calligraphy by Funakoshi and S?gen Asahina (1891–1979), chief priest of the temple, which reads Karate ni sente nashi (There is no first attack in karate), the second of Funakoshi’s twenty principles. To the right of Funakoshi’s precept is a copy of the poem he wrote on his way to Japan in 1922. A second stone features the inscription by Nobuhide Ohama.{r=54}

Contributions

Shotokan, the name on the sign posted by Funakoshi's students at his dojo, is derived from Funakoshi's pen name, Shoto, which means "waving pines." In addition to being a karate master, Funakoshi was an avid poet and philosopher who would reportedly go for long walks in the forest where he would meditate and write his poetry. Kan, which means training hall, or house; thus Shotokan means the "house of Shoto." By the late 1910s, Funakoshi had many students, of which a few were deemed capable of passing on their master's teachings.{r=54}

In 1912,{r=54} he became Chairman of Shobukai, the martial arts association of Okinawa.{r=52}

On March 6, 1921, Funakoshi led a public performance of karate by Naha First High School students for the visiting Crown Prince Hirohito at the Grand Hall of Shuri Castle. On May 6, 1922, he traveled to Tokyo and introduced karate at the First Budo and Physical Education Exhibition sponsored by the Ministry of Education; under the name “Karate Kenkyukai," he also gave lectures and demonstrations in Tokyo. These events led the militaristic Japanese establishment to see karate as useful, and Funakoshi was invited to visit again and stay.{r=55}

In 1922, Funakoshi moved to Japan to teach karate.{r=54} When he arrived, Funakoshi, but 4’11", was 54 years old. He stayed as a guest of Kano Jigoro, the founder of the first school of Judo, the Kodokan, and taught classes there. During this time, he began replacing Okinawan names with Japanese names for kata and using Kano’s uniform and belt rank system.{r=55} In 1929, he changed his writing of karate from “China hand" to “empty hand,"{r=56}. He felt that "China hand" would mislead people into thinking that karate directly originated from Chinese boxing, and argued in his autobiography that a philosophical evaluation of the use of "empty" seemed to fit as it implied a way which was not tethered to any other physical object.{r=54} In that same year, in his first book Ryukyu Boxing Karate, he changed "karate-jutsu" to "karate-do."{r=52} {n=Japan Karate Association of India. n.d. 8 Jan. 2014.}

It is difficult to prove the ways in which Funakoshi might have changed methods in teaching and practicing karate aside from making it more formalized, militaristic, and geared towards large classes.{r=55}

From 1924, Funakoshi started teaching Karate at various universities such as Tokyo, Takushoku, Waseda, Todai and Keio universities.{r=52} In 1930, to promote communication and information exchange among karate-ka, he established Dai-nihon Karate-do Kenkyukai, which changed its name in 1936 to Dai-nippon Karate-do Shoto-kai. From 1936 until his death in 1957, Funakoshi was the first Shoto-kai Chairman. In April of 1958, Dai-nihon Karate-do Shoto-Kai and Dai-nippon Karate-do Shoto-kan were reorganized into the present Nihon Karate-do Shoto-kai.{r=56} It is generally known today as Shotokai, and is the official keeper of Funakoshi’s karate heritage.{r=54}

On January 29, 1939, the Shotokan dojo in Zoshigaya, Toshima-ku was built, though it was burnt down on April 29, 1945 in the great Tokyo air raid. In the first year he created the Ten no Kata, Taikyoku Shodan, Taikyoku Nidan, Taikyoku Sandan (check conflict), and Kon no Matsukaze, and throughout this time was the first Shotokan Principal.{r=56}

After World War II, Funakoshi saw American interest in his Japanese karate the same way he had previously seen Japanese interest in his Okinawan Karate. Once again, he was able to provide the Americans with a demonstration of karate and a short instruction course to those interested.{r=55}

His notable students were Hironori ?tsuka, {p=18} (his son), {p=17}, Shigeru Egami, {p=6}, {p=7}, {p=3}, {p=4}, Tsutomu Ohshima, {p=11}, Mitsusuke Harada, {p=2}, and Won Kuk Lee.{r=54}

Approach

Mentioning in his own works that some karate movements were too dangerous for children, Funakoshi purportedly removed them without specifying which ones: while sport enthusiasts say that the simplification made techniques more streamlined and powerful, application enthusiasts claim that the removal made the techniques into mere exercise. According to Redmond, the excisions only affected Funakoshi’s creation of the Ten no Kata and the Taikyoku kata and not the rest of the martial art’s content.{r=55}

Funakoshi was not in favor of competitive karate, and he wrote in his autobiography that competition does not encourage positive traits like humility that are important in a Japanese citizen.{r=55}Nishiyama recalls studying under Funakoshi in the dojo or at the university in the forties and fifties, where Funakoshi and his son Gig? equally shared teaching responsibilities between each other. At the dojo, the training was about 80% kata and 20% kihon, and mistakes in kata would result in repetitions until there were no more mistakes. The first year and a half was spent on {k=2} alone. Funakoshi taught at the university once a week, where the training was much harder.{r=57}

Achievements

Funakoshi, at 5th dan, had the highest karate rank at that time.{r=54}

In 1949, his students created the Japan Karate Association ({o=1}), with Funakoshi as the honorary head of the organization;{r=54} this was to provide organizational and financial support for Funakoshi, who, like most true martial arts masters, was not financially successful.{r=53}{n=Black Belt Magazine Feb. 1988. 8 Jan. 2014} However, in practice, this organization was led by Masatoshi Nakayama, and Funakoshi was not supportive of all of the changes that the JKA eventually made to his karate style.{r=54} More specifically, his own students, including his son, rejected most of his ideas: his high stances, his kata, his kata’s techniques, his kata’s Japanese names, his methods, his marketing, and his philosophy. They preferred competitions and other kata, and the only similarities to his 1920s karate are in the basic movements of his kata.{r=55})

Commemorative public karate performances and ceremonies{r=56}:
- October 1988: the fiftieth anniversary of Shotokan.
- October 1992: the 70th anniversary of Funakoshi bringing karate to Japan.
- October 2002: the 80th anniversary of Funakoshi bringing Shotokan to Japan.
- April 1998: the 130th anniversary of Funakoshi’s birthday and the 60th anniversary of Shotokan.
- October 1998: the 130th anniversary of Funakoshi’s birthday and the 60th anniversary of Shotokan.
- March 1, 2009: the 140th anniversary of his birthday and the 70th anniversary of Shotokan.
- August 27, 1998: a “Pine of Appreciation" was planted at Sueyoshi Park, Naha for the 130th anniversary of Funakoshi’s birthday.

Publications

Funakoshi published several books on karate. Before World War II, his books catered to a militaristic readership: in Tote Jutsu he writes, “The shrunken military is like a folded umbrella; when necessary, it will be expanded to include citizens, so, citizens should practice at home…" In Rentan Goshin Karate Jutsu, he also writes, “Eternal peace is only a dream, however joyful a dream it may be. War is a method which God gave humans to organize the world." It was after Japan’s defeat in World War II, the American occupation, and the occupier’s ban on karate that he began to write a new philosophy of karate ni sente nashi: there is no first attack in karate.{r=55}br>
Funakoshi published an autobiography, Karate-Do: My Way of Life. His legacy, however, rests in a document containing his philosophies of karate training now referred to as the niju kun, or "twenty principles." These rules are the premise of training for all Shotokan practitioners and are published in a work titled The Twenty Guiding Principles of Karate. Within this book, Funakoshi lays out 20 rules by which students of karate are urged to abide in an effort to "become better human beings."{r=54}

Funakoshi's Karate-Do Kyohan: The Master Text, remains his most detailed publication, containing sections on history, basics, kata, and kumite; the famous Shotokan Tiger by Hoan adorns the hardback cover.{r=54}

Additional Reading

Redmond, Rob. "Deconstructing Funakoshi." 24 Fighting Chickens. Last modified January 29, 2006.

Hirokazu Kanazawa (?? ??) is a world-renowned Japanese master of Shotokan karate. He is the Chief instructor and President of the Shotokan Karate-Do International Federation ({o=2}), an organization he founded after he left the Japan Karate Association ({o=1}).{r=58}

Life

Kanazawa was born in Iwate Prefecture, Japan in 1931.{r=59} In high school, he earned a 2nd dan in judo, and after graduation enrolled at Nippon University. However, after seeing students of Takushoku University, the most active university in karate, practicing karate, he switched to their university to learn the art.{r=60} He decided upon karate because he saw that in karate, size would not be an advantage; he was 18 at the time. He studied under JKA head {p=3}, and is now one of the few remaining karateka to have studied under {p=1}.{r=61} He also studied under {p=4} and other senior instructors. While advancing in rank, he joined the JKA Instructor Training Program.{r=59}

In 1956, he graduated from the university.{r=58} In that year, he passed the instructor’s exam.{r=60} He was among the first to graduate from the instructor training program.{r=58} He joined the JKA and remained a member until leaving it and founding SKIF.{r=62}

During his karate career, Kanazawa has sustained many injuries: two broken hands, broken fingers, and injured shoulder and spine, and stitches over his right eye and right ear. He is quick to point out that these injuries were his own fault.{r=60}

Along with expertise in various traditional weaponry, Kanazawa has studied Tai Chi for over thirty years under professor Wong.{r=60} He has attained the highest possible rank in Tai Chi, and claims that its smooth and flowing movements balance the strong and powerful movements of his karate.{r=59}

Contributions

In 1958, Kanazawa provided much help in getting the JKA approved as a corporation by the Japanese Ministry of Education.{r=63}

In January 1961, Kanazawa was sent to Hawaii after the Butoku Karate Club requested a replacement instructor from the JKA. Aihara of Waseda University had arrived in July 1959 and taught at the Butoku Karate Club until he stopped teaching in late 1960. When Kanazawa arrived, he established a dojo as one of Hawaii’s first full time instructors, interacted with karate instructors of other styles who were already there, and became the first president of the Hawaii Karate Congress, an organization that existed until the 1990s. Some of his senior students include Francis Fong, Kenneth Funakoshi, Ed Kiyuna, Jimmy Miyaji, Stanley Ono, George Sasano, Harry Tagomori, Victor Takemori, and Eugene Watanabe.{r=64}

In May 1963, Kanazawa left Hawaii to teach in Europe and Japan, returning from time to time to teach. His last visit was in June 2003.{r=64}

In 1966, Kanazawa was sent to Great Britain, receiving his 6th dan while there{r=65} and becoming Chief Instructor of the Karate Union of Great Britain ({o=10}).{r=62} His British followers include John van Weenen.{r=65} He also taught in Germany.{r=59} In 1967, he became Chief Instructor of JKA Europe & German Karate Federation. In 1968 he was General Manager of the European team at the World Championship in Mexico.{r=62}

In 1971, he became the JKA Director & General Manager of the International Division of JKA and Shihan at Musashikogyo, Kantogakuin and Kitasato Universities. In 1972, he was General Manager of the Japanese Team at the 2nd WUKO Championship in Paris, France.{r=62}

Kanazawa broke away from the JKA in 1973, leaving it in 1977 and establishing Shotokan Karate-Do International (SKI).{r=62} In 1978, he set up SKI as SKIF. SKIF is now the worlds largest Shotokan Karate Association under one chief instructor, having several million members in over 130 countries,{r=61} and he continues to be the Chief Instructor and President{r=62} of his own organization. Despite leaving the JKA, he is reported to maintain some ties with former colleagues in that organization.{r=58}

Kanazawa has done much work in tournaments. He was referee in 1976 in the 1st IAKF World Championship in Los Angeles and the JKA Asia-Oceania Championship in Hong Kong, and chairman of the 1st through 9th SKIF World Championships (1983, 1985, 1991, 1994, 1997, 2000, 2003, 2006).{r=62}

In 1990, Kanazawa demonstrated his art at the 10th Traditional Karate Tournament International, held in Las Vegas. In 1994 and 1995, he demonstrated his art at the 14th and 15th Traditional Karate Tournaments International.{r=58}

Approach

The most important points in Kanazawa’s teaching are breathing, movement and timing. Breathing is foremost because it is the basis of body, mind, and spirit.{r=60}

He has developed his punch over time into one with a double kime: a physical focus followed by a speed focus. Kanazawa learned from correspondence with the famous Chinese martial arts teacher Matsuda Ryuchi that apparently, he had subconsciously developed a Chinese kempo punch.{r=60}

In defending his changing of kata, Kanazawa states that differences in kata have always existed through schools, personal interpretations, age, and physical capabilities.{r=60}

In kumite, he believes that winning technique needs only 60% power if 40% of the opponent’s power is used against him. Concentration of heart, mind, and soul also plays an extremely important part, in that the slightest distortion in thinking can cause serious injury of the practitioner or the opponent. He emphasizes this same concentration in basic forms and movements so that karate’s purpose of defeating the opponent may be attained.{r=60}

He has expressed regret over the lack of philosophical development in karate, both in the West and in Japan. He dislikes karate’s development as a sport, particularly as a mainly competitive fighting sport through the JKA. He states that such a trend has privileged it towards young, strong men, a contradiction against his own philosophy of karate being for everybody of all ages.{r=60}

Finally, he states, “Karate, through its physical and spiritual training and rigid principles, has taught me to control myself. I am confident that in no matter what kind of situation I am in, I would not carelessly use Karate to defend myself. One must always be in a defensive attitude and avoid entanglements for Karate seeks no advantage. In Karate you start with defense and end with defense."{r=60}

Achievements

After just a year and a half of training, he received shodan rank; after three more years, nidan, and sandan in 1956.3, 3 (The date of his 4th dan is unknown.) He received 5th dan in 1961,{r=58} 6th dan in 1966, and 7th dan in 1971 (up to this point, all JKA ranks). In 1973, the All Japan Karate Federation gave him 7th dan. The International Martial Arts Federation in 1978 gave him 8th dan, in 1988 9th dan, and in 2001 10th dan.{r=62} The website Fighting Master states differently that his 10th dan was given in April 2000 while attending the 7th SKIF World Championships in Bali.{r=60}

In 1957, Kanazawa, though nursing a broken wrist, was the first karateka to have won the kumite division in the inaugural year of the notorious All Japan Karate Championship.{r=61} He was not going to compete, but as his mother had come in from the country to watch him, he decided to enter in at least one match. A doctor had to check his injured wrist after each match. Using his left hand to fake and block and saving his bandaged right hand for the precise moment, he won all matches with clear one-point blows.{r=60} In the following year, he was kumite and kata champion{r=61} in the 2nd All Japan Karate Championship, sharing the kumite title with Takayuki Mikami. Because Mikami and Kanazawa had been classmates and roommates for a long time and knew each other well, they launched a minimal number of attacks, mainly just circling until the time was up; thus, they shared the kumite title.{r=58}

Kanazawa is the only karateka to have won the JKA All Japan Karate Championships three times in a row. In recent years, his eldest son Nobuaki has continued the winning tradition.{r=60}

Publications

Kanazawa has written many books on karate, which notably include: Karate: My life (2003), Karate: The Complete Kata (2010), Karate Fighting Techniques: The Complete Kumite (2004, co-authored), and Black Belt Karate (2006). He has been featured in Paul Walker's Lessons with the Master: 279 Karate Lessons with Master Hirokazu Kanazawa." Rare books are Stronger Karate in Six Weeks (1978) and Clive Layton’s Kanazawa, 10th Dan: Recollections of a Living Karate Legend - The Early Years (1931-1964).

A 9 DVD set with Kanazawa is Mastering Karate: Featuring Master Hirokazu Kanazawa. The titles are Te Waza, Ashi Waza, Kihon Ido, Kyu Kata, Dan Kata, Ni Ju Hachi Ho, Kumite, Interview with Kancho, and A Master Goes to Hollywood.{r=64}

Masatoshi Nakayama (?? ??) was an internationally renowned Japanese master of Shotokan karate. He helped establish the Japan Karate Association ({o=1}) and wrote many textbooks on karate, working for almost 40 years, until his death in 1987, to standardize and spread Shotokan karate around the world. He was the first master in Shotokan history to attain the rank of 9th dan while alive and was posthumously awarded the rank of 10th dan.{r=66}

Life

Nakayama was born on April 1913 in Yamaguchi Prefecture, Japan. He was descended from the Sanada clan of Nagano, a clan of highly-skilled kenjutsu instructors.{r=67} His grandfather was Naomichi Nakayama,{r=66} a surgeon in Tokyo and a kenjutsu instructor.{r=63} His father was also named Naomichi Nakayama,{r=66}, and was an army medic and a judoka.{r=63} When his father was assigned to Taipei, Nakayama spent some of his formative years there.{r=66} In his youth, he did kendo, judo, swimming, skiing, tennis, and athletics.{r=63}

In 1932, Nakayama passed the entrance exams to Takushoku University, intending to continue kendo{r=63}; but after misreading the schedule, he arrived at a karate class instead.{r=66} He observed university's karateka and was invited to the next class. He would say later, "I forgot kendo completely."{r=63} On joining, he trained under {p=1} and his son {p=18}.{r=67} Nakayama practiced karate for five hours a day. The training under Funakoshi of that time, consisting of fifty or sixty repetitions of a single kata and one thousand blows to a makiwara, was so exhaustive that only ten percent of the students lasted for more than six months.In autumn of 1936, Nakayama and other students of Funakoshi gave the first public exhibition of these new methods of training in a demonstration in the Civic Centre of Tokyo.{r=63}

In university, Nakayama studied history and Chinese language. He spent three or four months in Manchuria during 1933.{r=63} He graduated from Takushoku University in 1937 and returned to China.{r=66} Through an exchange program{r=63}, he enrolled in the University of Beijing's Institute of Eastern studies.{r=52} He remained to work for the Chinese government,{r=63}, and was a military interpreter during the Japanese occupation of China.{r=66} His stay in China spared him from the horrors of World War II Japan.{r=63}

In graduating from Takushoku University in 1937, Nakayama decided to devote his life to karate.{r=67} In China, he continued to practice and teach karate, as well as study Chinese martial arts,{r=63} until withdrawing from the University of Beijing in May 1946 and returning to Japan.{r=52}

Along with his role in the JKA, Nakayama also held positions in the Physical Education department of Takushoku University, beginning in 1952, and eventually became head of that department. He was also head of the ski team at the university.{r=66}

Until his death, Nakayama continued teaching, traveling, writing books on karate,{r=63} and as Chief Instructor{r=66} watching the JKA grow to a world-wide organization of more than 10 million people in 155 countries.{r=63} He passed away in Tokyo{r=66} in 1987 at seventy-four years of age, just as JKA was reaching a pinnacle.{r=69}

Contributions

When Nakayama returned to post-war Japan from China in 1946, he found the dojo in ruins, and that several of his karateka companions had perished.{r=63} He got together with other Shotokan colleages from his university days such as {p=1},{r=66}, and the students all moved to the university to train. The first split was already under way, though, as the junior students wanted Nakayama in charge, while the senior students wanted Obata in charge. This was because Nakayama was a full-time professional karate teacher, and Obata, as an architect, was not.{r=57}

In 1949, Nakayama and his colleagues established the JKA with Funakoshi as Supreme Master.{r=67} In 1955, a headquarters dojo was built at Yotsuya in Tokyo, spurring the building of JKA branch dojos all across Japan.{r=67} In 1952, Nakayama was head of physical instruction in the JKA.{r=63} 1958,{r=67} Funakoshi, then 81 years old and remaining honorary head of the JKA, chose Nakayama to be Chief Instructor of the JKA.{r=63}

In 1955, with the help of {p=6}, Nakayama developed the JKA instructor training program.{r=70} According to the JKA, this program is, and always has been, the only karate organization whose full time instructors continue to get together every day for joint practice.{r=67} During the period from 1957-1985 under Nakayama's guidance, the JKA, while greatly expanding its branch dojo throughout Japan, began sending (as early as 1958) some of its most highly-accomplished professional instructors overseas to America, Europe and the Middle East to teach and establish dojos. The JKA was the first karate organization to set up dojo outside Japan, and the only organization to send full time instructors to teach karate at universities. For these reasons the JKA is so prominent and powerful overseas.{r=69}

Nakayama also invented karate’s first match system: the first JKA All Japan Karate Championship was held at Tokyo Metropolitan Gymnasium in October, 1957, and was attended by so many participants and spectators that the venue was filled to capacity. The 5th JKA All Japan Karate Championship in 1961 was even attended by the Crown Prince of Japan (now the Emperor of Japan).{r=67}

His adaptation of kata and kumite for the match system was a huge success,{r=67} and students of the large JKA dojo achieved an unmatched series of tournament successes in the 1950s and 1960s.{r=66}

In 1972, with the help of {p=2},{r=71}, Nakayama made his personal dojo in the basement of his apartment building, along with a small dormitory for international karateka.{r=72} The building was basically built around the dojo, with the Nakayama residence at the top of this 6-story apartment building,{r=71} and is located in Ebisu-Nishi, Tokyo, just around the corner from where the hombu dojo had been for over two decades. He named the dojo Hoitsugan after the name of the first place he stayed at when studying in China. The name most closely translates as “the place where people with similar goals practice and study together” and is a reflection of his desires to develop karate as a means of fostering friendships and improving international relations. Over the years hundreds, if not thousands,{r=72} have lived there, sometimes for years, to live the budo lifestyle and train under the best instructors, winners of the All Japan and ShotoCup tournaments.{r=73} Today, though the original dormitory is no longer being used today as a living space,{r=71} Kawawada Sensei, with the support of Mrs. Nakayama, continues to carry on the legacy of the Hoitsugan dojo.{r=72}

Until his death, Nakayama attended every ISKF Master Camp, a summer camp that invites karate masters from around the world, traditionally from the United States, Europe, Japan, Africa, and Canada.{r=70}

After Nakayama's death in 1987, the JKA divided into two factions, which subsequently led to a further splintering within the organization. Many senior JKA instructors left to form their own associations, which include the International Shotokan Karate Federation ({o=3}, Teruyuki Okazaki), Japan Karate Shotokai ({o=6}, {p=7}), Japan Shotokan Karate Association ({o=11}, ), Shotokan Karate International ({o=2} Hirokazu Kanazawa), and Karatenomichi World Federation ({o=5} {p=5}). All of these instructors were students of Nakayama's. Other notable students were {p=8} and Takayuki Mikami.{r=66}

Approach

Nakayama's generation, in practising Judo or Kendo, were accustomed to several types of encounter against a real antagonist; this experience was used in the development of karate.{r=63} In 1956, Nakayama, with Okazaki and other JKA instructors,{r=66} restructured the Shotokan karate training program to into a new method of teaching that was tailored to the level and goals of each student: karate as a physical development tool, as a method of self-defense, and as tournament disciplines. He emphasized the necessity for each aspect of training to be physically and kinesthetically practical, and he scientifically analyzed how to make them so.{r=67} For the first time, there emerged the “best” form for each kumite stance, posture and movement, and a clear delineation between the “correct” and “incorrect” way to execute each stance, punch, kick or technique.{r=69}

Nakayama was also a staunch supporter of spreading karate to the world and letting each culture adopt and spread karate in their homelands. He wanted to present karate-do in the context of each country’s culture and in a democratic fashion.{r=70}

Teruyuki Okazaki (?? ??), a tenth degree black belt in Shotokan Karate, is the founder, chairman and chief instructor of the International Shotokan Karate Federation (ISKF). Along with Gichin Funakoshi and Masatoshi Nakayama, Okazaki helped found the Japan Karate Association's instructor training program.

Life

Okazaki was born in Fukuoka Prefecture, Japan. As a young man, he grew up studying judo, kendo, and aikido. In 1948, at the age of sixteen, he entered Takushoku University. It was here that Okazaki began his karate training. Teruyuki Okazaki studied primarily under Gichin Funakoshi as well as Masatoshi Nakayama. In 1953, Okazaki graduated and was immediately appointed coach of the Takushoku team. Later that year, it was decided that Okazaki would be trained as a "test case" for the still formulating JKA Instructor Trainee Program.

In 1961, Okazaki moved to the United States. Although he has spent most of his adult life promoting Shotokan throughout North America, he has also held a faculty position at Philadelphia’s Temple University since 1970 and is an instructor at the University of Pennsylvania, Drexel University, West Chester University, and Thomas Jefferson University.

Contributions and Career

In 1955, he was appointed head of the JKA Instructor Trainee Program, which produced some of modern Shotokan's most integral leaders. Takayuki Mikami, Eiji Takaura, and Hirokazu Kanazawa were among the first graduates from this program.

As part of an effort by Nakayama to spread the practice of Shotokan karate internationally, Okazaki came to the United States in 1961, originally planning to stay only six months, but has since opened a dojo in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania and settled there permanently.

In 1977, Okazaki founded the International Shotokan Karate Federation. In April 2007 Okazaki proposed, as chief instructor of the ISKF, termination of the ISKF's relationship with the JKA and formed an external independent body. This motion was supported by 25 other countries which continued their relationship with the ISKF and discontinued relations with the JKA. This decision came following Okazaki's concern that the JKA had not been conducting itself in the manner appropriate to the teachings of Master Gichin Funakoshi.

At the following Canadian National ISKF Championships in Toronto, Canada in October 2007, the ISKF technical committee announced Okazaki's promotion to 10th dan, the highest ranking karate master in the ISKF, and among only a couple others internationally at the time. Yutaka Yaguchi was also promoted to the rank of 9th dan and is now Vice Chairman and Vice Chief Instructor of the ISKF and Chairman of the Technical Committee of the ISKF.

Tetsuhiko Asai (?? ??) was a prominent Japanese master of Shotokan karate who was a former Technical Director of the Japan Karate Association (JKA), founder and Chief Instructor of the International Japan Martial Arts Karate Asai-ryu (IJKA), and founder of the Japan Karate Shoto-Renmei (JKS; also known as the Japan Karate Shoto Federation).

Life

Asai was born in Ehime Prefecture (on the island of Shikoku), Japan. As a boy, he trained in sumo. In addition, his father, a policeman, taught him judo, kendo, and sojutsu (spear). When he was 12 years old, he witnessed a fight between a boxer and a karateka; the karate combatant was able to disable his opponent with a kick, and Asai was impressed.

In 1958, Asai graduated from Takushoku University, where he had trained in karate under Gichin Funakoshi, Masatoshi Nakayama, and Teruyuki Okazaki. He trained hard and was allowed to sleep in the karate dormitory. At Nakayama's recommendation, he entered the JKA instructor training program and graduated from the course three years later.

Asai won the JKA championship in kumite in 1961, and in kata in 1963. He was overall JKA champion in 1961, having come first in kumite and second in kata that year.

Apart from the ranking of 9th dan in Shotokan karate, he also held the ranks of 3rd dan in jodo, 2nd dan in judo, 2nd dan in jukendo, and 2nd dan in kendo.

Asai's health deteriorated with age. More than 2,000 people attended his funeral, which was held on September 1, 2006, at Gokokuji Temple in Tokyo. Asai received the rank of 10th dan posthumously from the JKS, and was succeeded as President of the IJKA by his widow.

Contributions and Career

Asai became the first instructor to introduce karate to Taiwan. Through the second half of the 1960s, he taught karate in Hawaii for five years, with his students including Kenneth Funakoshi (a fourth cousin to Gichin Funakoshi).

Over the years, Asai advanced within the JKA, and was appointed as Technical Director. Following Nakayama's death, the JKA experienced political troubles and divided; Asai and colleagues (including Keigo Abe and Mikio Yahara) formed one group, while Nakahara Nobuyuki and colleagues formed another group—which in 1999 was officially recognized as the JKA. Reflecting on relations between JKA instructors who had graduated from Takushoku University, Asai said, "we all pretty much get on nowadays, contrary to our official stances and federations. In saying that, some of us don't, but isn't that life? ... I am happy to say that most of the deep rooted rivalry has gone amongst my peers. I think that the passing of Mr. Enoeda, Mr. Kase, Mr. Tabata and Mr. Shoji and so forth has brought many of us back to reality. Obviously this is not limited to Takushoku University, it is all about us international karate pioneers getting very old."

In 2000, he founded the International Japan Martial Arts Karate Asai-ryu and the Japan Karate Shoto-Renmei. Since he passed away, IJKA in Europe has apparently separated from K. Asai's IJKA. In 2013, Asai Shotokan Association International (ASAI) was formed by a former student of Asai, Kousaku Yokota, to propagate Asai's style of Shotokan.

Keinosuke Enoeda (?? ???) was a Japanese master of Shotokan karate and a former Chief Instructor of the Karate Union of Great Britain. Enoeda was ranked 8th dan in Shotokan karate, and was widely renowned as a formidable karateka. Following his death, Enoeda was posthumously awarded the rank of 9th dan.

Life

Enoeda was born on the island of Kyushu, Japan. As a youth, he trained in kendo and judo, and played baseball. By the age of 16, Enoeda had reached the rank of 2nd dan in judo. He entered Takushoku University and, being impressed by a karate demonstration there, began studying that martial art.

After graduating from university, Enoeda studied at the Japan Karate Association (JKA) honbu dojo in Tokyo under Masatoshi Nakayama, then the JKA's Chief Instructor. He also trained in kumite under the direction of Taiji Kase. In 1961, he fought a notable tournament match against Keigo Abe, winning by decision after six extensions. He won the JKA All Japan Championship in 1963 against another well known karateka, Hiroshi Shirai. During this period, Enoeda acquired the nickname Tora ("Tiger") after Nakayama had described his fighting.

In moving to England in 1965, Enoeda and his wife, Reiko (married in 1969), settled in Kingston, Surrey.

Contributions and Career

On 20 April 1965, following the JKA's policy of sending instructors abroad to introduce karate to the rest of the world, Enoeda travelled to England with JKA instructors Shirai, Kanazawa, and Kase. He began teaching in Liverpool. One of Enoeda's British students in the late 1960s was karate scholar Harry Cook.

In 1973, Enoeda led a demonstration of karate on live television for the BBC. Part of the Open Door series, it was the first British TV program entirely about karate. The demonstration included kihon, kata, Enoeda sparring multiple opponents, Enoeda against Tomita with a large blade, and Dave Hazard breaking a piece of Japanese hardwood.

While Chief Instructor of the KUGB, Enoeda was assisted by: Sadashige Kato (from c. 1966–1973), Shiro Asano (from 1968–1974), Hideo Tomita (from 1973–1978), Masao Kawasoe (from 1974–1982), and Yoshinobu Ohta (from 1982–2003). In 1985, he was ranked 8th dan.

Enoeda promoted his dojo with "Dynamic Karate" posters on the London Underground. He continued teaching karate, at the Marshall Street Baths near Carnaby Street in London, until his death in 2003; shortly after his death, the JKA awarded the rank of 9th dan to him.

Publications

Enoeda wrote several books on karate, including: Shotokan: Advanced Kata (1983, in at least two volumes), Shotokan Karate (1996), Shotokan Karate: 10th Kyu to 6th Kyu (1996), Shotokan Karate: 5th Kyu to Black Belt (1996), Karate: Defense & Attack (1996, co-authored), and Shotokan Karate: Free Fighting Techniques (1999, co-authored).

Hiroshi Shirai (?? ?) is a Japanese master of Shotokan karate. He is the founder of the Instituto Shotokan Italia, a subdivision of FIKTA (the Italian Traditional Karate Association) and of the SCI (Shotokan Cultural Institute, formerly WSI - World Shotokan Institute). Shirai holds the title of Shihan and is responsible for taking the dan examinations within SCI and, together with Carlo Fugazza, for those within the FIKTA.

Life

Shirai was born on 31 July 1937 in Nagasaki, Japan. He started learning karate in 1956, three years after seeing a promotional video of the Japan Karate Association (JKA) at Komazawa University. He received 1st dan a year, the 2nd in 1959, and the 3rd in 1961.

In 1962, he won both the kata and the kumite championships of the JKA, thereby becoming one of those receiving the title 'Grand Champion'.

He moved to Italy in 1965. By then, he was 5th dan, as achieved the year before; the year in which he received his 4th is unknown.

Contributions and Career

After a world trip to promote karate together with Taiji Kase, Kano, and Keinosuke Enoeda to Europe, South Africa, and the United States of America, he settled in Milan, Italy in 1965. Under his tutelage the Italian karate flourished and many titles went to his students.

Shirai feels that the self-defence (goshindo) aspect of Shotokan karate has been too much in the shadow of kumite and kata. After moving to Europe, he started refocusing on self-defence and its incorporation in the practise of Shotokan karate. During the last years Shirai has given special goshindo oriented stages in Europe often together with Claudio Ceruti, Massimo Abate, and Angelo Torre.

For the practise of goshindo, Shirai has developed several kihon training methods focusing on simple, powerful and effective techniques, almost always executed in a frontal stance towards the opponent. Turning, in order to achieve this stable frontal stance, is a basic principle of Shirai's goshindo. In addition to kihon, he developed specific goshindo kata. These kata stress the importance of being able to address an attacker coming from any direction. Several of these kata include grabbing and open hand techniques, elements not so often seen in 'normal' Shotokan karate.

His graduation history since then his move is as follows: 6th - 1969; 7th - 1974; 8th - 1986, 9th - 1999. His current rank, 10th dan, was received in 2011.

Keigo Abe (?? ??) is a prominent Japanese master of Shotokan karate who founded the Japan Shotokan Karate Association in 1999 and is its Chief Instructor. He holds the rank of 9th dan in karate, is a direct student of Masatoshi Nakayama (1913–1987), and was a senior instructor in the Japan Karate Association.

Life

Abe was born in the town of Iyoshi, Ehime Prefecture (on the island of Shikoku), Japan. Abe's ancestors included samurai; he has told of an incident from the past where two thieves had entered his family home, saying, "My family killed them; the two graves are still standing near my house." In 1953, aged 15 years, he began training in the martial arts of karate and judo. He initially began studying the Shito-ryu style of karate.

In 1956, Abe entered the Nihon University in Tokyo, studying engineering, and graduated four years later. He began training at the honbu dojo of the Japan Karate Association (JKA) in 1958 under Masatoshi Nakayama. In an interview in 2000, he said, "Nakayama Sensei was very serious. He trained us very hard and always encouraged us to not only train hard, but to intellectually study what we were training. He stressed understanding ourselves and being good human beings." He graduated from the JKA instructors' training program in 1965.

In 1961, Abe fought a notable tournament match against Keinosuke Enoeda, losing by decision after six extensions. Nakayama wrote that Abe's strengths were his backfist technique and his use of distancing, strengths also noted by others years later. He had an accomplished record as a karate tournament competitor, taking first place in the inaugural JKA National Championship, first place in the team competition at the 1973 JKA International Friendship Tournament, and first place in the second and third Japan Karatedo Federation National Championships (representing Tokyo).

Through Nakayama, Abe worked on the James Bond film "You Only Live Twice" (1967). Nakayama had been invited to appear in the movie, but was unable to do so due to prior commitments, and so recommended Abe instead.

Regarding training in multiple martial arts, Abe has said, "In the old days the Bushi (warriors) would train in maybe 18 different arts out of battlefield necessity ... yes I would recommend cross-training." Apart from karate, he has also practiced iaido for more than 30 years, and also teaches this martial art. In his 60s, he was still training four or five mornings each week, involving karate practice and weight training, as well as teaching karate in Tokyo.

Contributions and Career

Abe was a long-serving member of the instructing team at JKA's honbu dojo. Like other kenshusei (junior instructors) of the day, Abe would practice his techniques on the streets against local gangsters to improve his fighting skills. Abe had a close working relationship with Nakayama, benefiting from his technical knowledge and assisting him with teaching. He was one of several instructors who demonstrated techniques in Nakayama's books on karate. In 1985, two years before Nakayama's death, Abe was appointed as Director of Qualifications in the JKA. After the division of the JKA in 1990, he became the Technical Director of the JKA (Matsuno faction). He was responsible for formulating the ippon shobu tournament rules, which are used by most Shotokan karate competitors today.

Abe resigned from the JKA (Matsuno faction) on January 31, 1999. On February 10, 1999, he formed his own organization, the Japan Shotokan Karate Association (JSKA). When asked about his organization in 2000, he said, "Unlike most leaders of Karate organizations, I do not want my organization to grow very large. Very large organizations mean very large problems. I want a smaller organization where I can be an active part of everyone’s life and a high degree of quality can be maintained."

Abe visited Australia in January 2008 and Cyprus in May 2009. In 2010, Abe was due to teach in several European countries, most notably at the 5th JSKA World Karate Championship in Portugal, as well as visiting Estonia, Iran, Israel, Mexico, and the United States of America.

Taiji Kase (?? ??) was a Japanese master of Shotokan karate who was one of the earliest masters responsible for introducing this martial art into Europe. He taught his style of karate, Shotokan Ryu Kase Ha, in France from the late 1960s to the mid-1980s. In his later years, he travelled across the world teaching karate, but Paris remained his home. Kase held the rank of 9th dan in karate.

Life

Kase was born in Chiba, Chiba Prefecture, Japan. His father was Nobuaki Kase, who held the rank of 5th dan in judo. He began learning judo before he turned 6 years old, and later in boyhood also studied aikido and kendo.

In 1944, at the age of 15 years, Kase attained the rank of 2nd dan black belt in judo. That same year, he read a book on karate by Gichin Funakoshi, and was inspired to begin studying that art under Funakoshi himself. He also trained under Funakoshi's son, Gigo Funakoshi, before the latter's death in 1945. Genshin Hironishi took on most of the teaching duties from that point. Along with Hironishi, Tadao Okuyama also influenced the young Kase's development in karate. Of his four instructors, Hironishi taught him the longest—six years. Kase had been due to be tested for his 3rd dan in judo, but elected to focus on karate instead.

In March 1945, during the closing stages of World War II, Kase enlisted in the Imperial Japanese Navy and joined the Kamikaze corps. The war ended, however, before he was required to give up his life for his country. One of his biographers, Martin Fernandez, wrote: "[Kase] usually says that since he could have died in the war and is alive, he never has a reason to be sad. And this is so, because you can always see him smiling or with a special inner mood." The Shotokan dojo had been destroyed by bombing, and he was unable to find another karate dojo, so he returned to training in judo for a while. When the Shotokan students regrouped under Funakoshi, however, he rejoined them.

In 1946, Kase was promoted to 1st dan in Shotokan karate. He began studying economics at Senshu University and, in 1949, became captain of the university's karate team. That same year, he attained the rank of 3rd dan. He graduated from Senshu University in 1951, and his professional karate career followed thereafter.

Kase suffered a heart attack on 31 May 1999, but recovered at the American Hospital of Paris. Following his recovery, he returned to teaching karate. On 6 November 2004, Kase became critically ill, and was hospitalised; he returned home later on, but on the morning of 19 November his wife was unable to wake him, and he later passed away. At the time, Kase held the rank of 9th dan. His funeral was held at the crematorium of Père Lachaise Cemetery, Paris.

Contributions and Career

Kase joined the newly formed Japan Karate Association (JKA) with the aim of becoming a professional karate instructor, and would later become Chief Instructor for the European branch of the JKA. One of his duties in the JKA was to train instructors in kumite; amongst his students were Keinosuke Enoeda and Hiroshi Shirai. Following Funakoshi's death in 1957 and a subsequent division in the JKA, Kase maintained ties with both factions.

In 1964, Kase left Japan to introduce karate overseas. That year, he taught for three months in South Africa, and continued teaching there the next year with Enoeda, Shirai, and Hirokazu Kanazawa. From 1965 to 1966, he taught in the United States of America, West Germany, the Netherlands, and Belgium. In 1967, he taught with Shirai in Italy for several months, and then travelled to France, where he settled in Paris. In 1968, Kase was coach of the French Karate Federation. He went on to teach karate there for almost 20 years in France before deciding to close his dojo in the mid-1980s. Amongst his European students was Steve Cattle, who founded the English Shotokan Academy. He then began travelling around the world to teach karate. Kase was frequently a guest of the former Yugoslav Karate Association, and almost all of the senior Yugoslav karate instructors gained their dan ranks through examinations in which he was involved.

In 1989, Kase and Shirai founded the World Karate-Do Shotokan Academy (WKSA). Kase has called his style of karate "Shotokan Ryu Kase Ha," meaning Shotokan with Kase's personal touch. Although he was travelling around the world promoting his style of karate, Paris remained his home. In June 2005, following his death, Kase's widow, Chieko Kase, became honorary President of the Kase Ha Shotokan Ryu Karate-Do Instructors' Academy.

Publications

During his time in France, Kase wrote books on his martial art, including 5 Heian: Katas, Karaté, Shotokan (1974), 18 kata supérieurs: Karate-dô Shôtôkan Ryû (1982), and Karaté-dô kata: 5-Heian, 2-Tekki (1983).

Masaaka Ueki (?? ??) is a Japanese master of Shotokan karate.

Life

Ueki started karate at the age of sixteen during his third year of high school under Sugiura, with only one other student participating. Despite beginning with judo, he found himself too small, but became interested in karate because of its emphasis on speed. Therefore he trained and developed throughout school, and after graduating from Asia University, he was encouraged to join the instructor’s program.

As a young man, he was also very interested in competition, and at the 8th JKA All Japan Karate Championship (1965), he became tournament Grand Champion, placing 1st in kata and 2nd in kumite, improving on this three years later at the 11th JKA All Japan Karate Championship (1968) where again he was tournament Grand Champion placing 1st in kumite and 1st in kata. He was tournament Grand Champion in 1971 after winning 1st in kata and 2nd in kumite, and won 1st place in kata in 1967, 1974, and 1975, and 2nd place in kata in 1966.

Contributions and Career

Ueki was also used in Nakayama’s Best Karate series. Of Ueki, M. Nakayama wrote ‘the hands and feet of Masaaki Ueki are worth watching, for they are very fast and truly sharp. It is not surprising that many opponents have been defeated’.

In the 1990 JKA legal dispute, Ueki was with Nakahara's group. Ueki still teaches today, and holding an 9th Dan grade, is the most senior Instructor of Japan Karate Association. His karate places a deep emphasis on very strong basics and stances, and he believes to fully appreciate and totally benefit from kata training, one needs to pull the kata apart.

Famed for his brilliant fighting spirit and hard fighting style, Masahiko Tanaka remains one of the greatest fighters to have emerged from the JKA heyday. M. Nakayama, former Chief instructor of the JKA, wrote, ‘There are very few competitors who can use both hands and feet with as much skill as Masahiko Tanaka’.

Life

Tanaka was born in Tokyo. He started karate in his second year at Japan University.

His major tournament wins are all in kumite: 3rd place in the 1973 16th JKA All Japan Karate Championship, 1st in the 1974 17th and the 1975 18th JKA All Japan Karate Championships, 1st in the 1975 1st and 1977 2nd IAKF World Karate Championships, and 1st in group kumite in the 1980 3rd IAKF World Karate Championship.

Contributions and Career

Tanaka was amongst the Nakahara group during the JKA legal dispute in 1990. Today, he is the Vice Chief Instructor of the JKA, and when he is not teaching at the JKA Honbu and maintaining the standards of the JKA, he often travels the world teaching seminars.

Publications

Tanaka, author of the famous Perfecting Kumite textbook, was also featured in M. Nakayama’s Best Karate series.

Chief Technical Director of the Japan Karate Shotorenmei, Masao Kagawa sensei is considered to be one of the best technicians to have graduated from the infamous JKA instructors’ course.

Having competed successfully both nationally and internationally, Kagawa sensei now concentrates his efforts on the JKS and the Japan Karate Federation national teams. With support from the elite members of JKS Hombu Dojo instructors and having studied Asai Sensei’s karate for many years, Kagawa sensei is well prepared to take the JKS to its next level of development. He is 8th dan in JKS, and 6th dan through the All Japan Union.

Life

Kagawa was born in Osaka, the younger brother of Masayoshi Kagawa, an All Japan Champion and a JKA instructor in Osaka. He began karate when 17 years old. He studied law in Teikyo University, where Abe was teaching.

After graduation in 1980, Kagawa attended the JKA Instructor Class. At the time, the main instructors were Nakayama, Asai, Tanaka, Ueki, and Abe.

After finishing the instructor course, he trained under Nakayama for seven years. Shaun Banfield, in interviewing Kagawa, describes Kagawa's telling of Nakayama's one bit of advice to him: "Sensei laughed here whilst pulling his hand to his hip representing ‘hikite’ without saying a word emphasising that Nakayama Sensei never actually said one word to him the entire time he know him." Under Asai, through assistance and observation, he learned the relaxed approach to technique; at this time, he also worked on his flexibility.

During his competitive years, he modeled himself on Yahara Sensei and Yamamoto Sensei. The head coach during that time was Asai, with Abe and Tanaka below him. In 1983, he won 1st place in group kata at the World Cup Karate Championship and 3rd place in group kumite at the IAKF World Championship, in 2nd place in kata and kumite at the 1984 27th JKA All Japan Karate Championship, 1st place in kata and kumite at the 1985 28 JKA All Japan Karate Championship, 1st place in group kata at the 1986 6th WKF World Championship, 3rd place in kumite at the 1989 32nd JKA All Japan Karate Championship, and the title of World Shotokan Karate Champion and 1st place in kata and kumite at the 1999 World JKA Karate Championship.

On kumite since then, in the Banfield interview, he said, "Before it was a bit stiller, but still very intense. Before, you didn’t throw as many techniques, you would go for the ippon. Now there’s a lot of movement, a lot of techniques, and it’s all about timing. ...I know that people believe that there is sport karate and there is Traditional karate, and they can see a difference, but all of my team are Traditional Karateka... My belief is that they are the same if done correctly."

He is known for Sochin, his kicks, and for emphasizing in his lessons relaxation and sharp kime. His favorite kata, though, is Bassai Dai, which he did for both his 1st and 8th dan exams. His practice in kata has been in learning how to use the body, and he believes that in order to have balance in karate, it is important to practice all types of kata.

Contributions and Career

Kagawa was a former JKA instructor.

Considered to be one of the best instructors in Japan at the present time, he is head coach for the JKF national squad and chief instructor of the JKS Hombu Dojo and JKS Instructor’s Course. As JKS Chief Technical Director, he is working towards developing wheelchair karate. He wants JKS to continue the line of Funakoshi, Nakayama, and Asai, and to continue to promote JKS around the world.

Masao Kawasoe is the head of the United Kingdom Traditional Karate Federation (UKTKF), an organization associated with the Japanese Karate Association and the International Traditional Karate Federation.1

Life

Masao Kawasoe was born in 1945. His father was a Japanese businessman, and he has two brothers.1

He began his martial arts training in judo. When he was 15, he saw a karate demonstration that so impressed him that he started looking for a karate dojo for training. One of his first instructors was Sensei Tsuyuma, who lived in the same town of Saga1 and is now Technical Director of the Japan Karate Federation.3 He trained through high school and his years at Takushoku University, where he continued to train with Sensei Tsuyuma.1

He trained six days per week, three hours per day, for four years. During this time he was spotted by the JKA and invited to join the full time JKA instructor training program under Masatoshi Nakayama. When he graduated three years later as an international JKA instructor, Nakayama said of him: “Through his mastery of karate basics, he has come to reach a level few achieve; his technique inspires all who see it to strive for the ideals of Shotokan karate.”1

Sensei Kawasoe continues to teach and has now been residing in London for over nineteen years.1

Contributions

After completing the JKA instructor program, Kawasoe was sent to teach in Taiwan and Madagascar before coming to Britain in 1974. During this time, with Kenny Taylor, he made many friendships with European instructors, as well as lifelong friendships with top Japanese instructors.1

In 1990, he formed the UKTKF within the UK. He had the support of many followers from his travels and teachings throughout Europe, and had good relationships with most of the large Shotokan organizations within those countries. The UKTKF, with Kawasoe as head and Kenny Taylor as President, now spans over 11 countries.1

The organization joined ITKF with Hidetaka Nishiyama.1 The UKTKF is still in active membership with ITKF, with Kawasoe as the ITKF's Technical Director.3. The UKTKF's athletes compete on a regular basis in European and World Championships with ITKF.1

Kawasoe regularly holds courses for both members and non-members throughout the UK, with contact information on this page of the official website.1

Approach

In the fourth volume of Nakayama’s Best Karate, he said, “Kawasoe is especially noted for his kicks, which are strong, good, effective and have a sharp snap."2

Kawasoe, in continuing his positive tone, has said, "I am lucky to have good karate, but even more I am lucky to have good students to carry it forward. My wish is to leave something worthwhile behind for everyone. My life is then complete.”

On his website, it is stated that his only criteria is that “you must put your gi on" and "train with a good heart."

Publications

Sensei Kawasoe has published the Beginner to Black Belt DVD set. It is demonstrated by Kawasoe himself and is a comprehensive resource for any beginner to karate.2

Isao Obata (?? ?) was a pioneering Japanese master of Shotokan karate. He was a senior student of Gichin Funakoshi and was a key figure in the establishment of the Japan Karate Association (JKA) under Funakoshi in 1949. Obata also helped introduce karate to the United States of America through his demonstrations of the art to United States Air Force personnel and through his students, most notably Tsutomu Ohshima.

His Life

Obata was born in 1904 in the Tokyo area of Japan. His father owned several silk mills in the region, and moved the family to different towns as demanded by his work. As a child, he had a great interest in the martial arts, and left it to his brother, Satoru, to prepare to lead the family business eventually. His father was too busy with his business to have studied the martial arts himself, but was pleased at his son's commitment to karate; one of the family's ancestors had been Obata Nobusada, a famous general and governor under daimyo (feudal lord) Takeda Shingen in the 16th century. At school, Obata trained in judo, kendo, and kyudo (archery). A friend gave him a copy of Gichin Funakoshi's first book on karate, and this sparked Obata's interest in the art.

Upon completion of his secondary education, Obata gained entry to Keio University. In 1923, Funakoshi accepted a position teaching karate at the university, and Obata would go on to become one of Funakoshi's senior students. The Great Kanto Earthquake struck later that year, destroying most of Tokyo, including Keio University's karate dojo (training hall). The students rebuilt the dojo within a year, however, and training resumed. Over the next few years, Obata assisted Funakoshi with teaching karate at Takushoku University, Waseda University, and Hitotsubashi University (then known as Shoka University). He became the inaugural captain of Keio University's karate club. In 1926, Funakoshi awarded black belt status to his most senior students, including Obata.

In 1932, Obata travelled to Manchuria, and was to work there for more than 10 years as an economic adviser to the Manchurian Aviation Corporation. During this time, he taught karate privately to a few friends and students, but turned his focus to kyudo. His mother introduced him to a young woman, Miyako, and the two were married in Tokyo by 1935. In 1940, he returned to Tokyo to represent Manchuria at a kyudo tournament, and won the competition. For a time, he was much better known for his expertise in kyudo than in karate.

During the first few months of World War II, Obata was promoted to the rank of 5th dan in Shotokan karate. When Japan entered the war, Obata's brother Satoru joined the Imperial Japanese Army as an officer. S. Obata had practised judo and was ranked 2nd dan in karate. He died in the bitter fighting for Iwo Jima, and this meant that Obata had to return to Japan to look after his mother and sister. His brother's death affected him deeply, for the two had been very close. With the end of the war, the occupying forces suspended all martial arts training in Japan for three years; it was only then that Obata could resume training under Funakoshi. In the meantime, he worked at international trading company Hirano Seiko.

In his final years, Obata lived with his wife in the outskirts of Tokyo, spending his days teaching karate or tending to his garden. While officially retired, he continued teaching four nights and four evenings each week at Keio University and Meiji University. His students presented him with a plaque reading: "Like your nickname, Elephant, you are strong, big and gentle. We thank you for the lessons you have taught us."

Karate Career

On May 27, 1949, Obata, Masatoshi Nakayama, Shigeru Egami, and other colleagues established the Japan Karate Association (JKA) under Funakoshi. Obata was the inaugural Chairman of the JKA, with Funakoshi as Honorary Chief Instructor and Nakayama as Chief Instructor. In 1954, he left the JKA when the organization became increasingly commercial and militaristic in nature. Along with Nakayama, Hidetaka Nishiyama, and others, he began teaching personnel from the US Strategic Air Command (SAC) who were based in Japan. Through Emilio Bruno of the SAC, whom Obata had earlier met through his work at Hirano Seiko, SAC headquarters invited Obata to visit the US to demonstrate his art. For two months in 1953, he flew from base to base, demonstrating Shotokan karate to US military personnel; he then returned to teaching in Japan.

Obata's master, Funakoshi, died in 1957. While Funakoshi had been honorary head of the JKA, Obata felt that the university karate clubs (Keio, Waseda, Takushoku, Hitotsubashi, and Hosei) most faithfully represented the spirit of Funakoshi's karate. Through the 1950s and 1960s, Obata continued teaching karate to SAC personnel at the Kodokan. In 1968, he visited the US again and was honored by his student Tsutomu Ohshima, who had established the Southern California Karate Association. Another pioneer of karate in California, Dan Ivan, also studied under Obata. In a 1972 interview, Obata expressed disillusionment with the development of karate, saying, "Karate is dying now. It cannot last longer than a few more decades."
